message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus and rhinovirus are both non-enveloped viruses, which are more resistant to disinfectants like alcohol compared to enveloped viruses like herpesvirus and coronavirus. Therefore, Adenovirus and rhinovirus are more likely to still be alive after cleaning with alcohol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only adenovirus and rhinovirus have a lipid envelope that can be inactivated by alcohol-based disinfectants. Adenovirus is also resistant to drying, so it can survive for some time on surfaces even after being inactivated by alcohol, making it the most likely organism to still be alive after the cleaning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Rhinoviruses are more resistant to alcohol-based disinfectants, thus they are the most likely to survive after cleaning the benchtop with alcohol. All other options are either not well suited to alcohol-based disinfectants or are highly susceptible to them.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus and rhinovirus are both non-enveloped viruses, making them more resistant to alcohol disinfection. The other options contain enveloped viruses, which are more susceptible to alcohol disinfection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus and rhinovirus are both non-enveloped viruses, which are more resistant to disinfection compared to enveloped viruses like herpesvirus and coronavirus. The use of alcohol in cleaning may not completely kill non-enveloped viruses, which can survive on surfaces for days.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol is an effective disinfectant against most viruses but rhinovirus is more resistant to alcohol than many other types of viruses. Adenoviruses can be inactivated by alcohol, while herpesvirus and coronavirus are more sensitive to it. Therefore, the most likely organisms to still be alive after the cleaning are adenovirus and rhinovirus, making choice (B) the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Rhinovirus is known to survive on surfaces for longer periods of time and is more resistant to alcohol disinfection compared to other viruses, including those listed in the options. Therefore, Adenovirus and Rhinovirus are the most likely viruses that would still be alive after the cleaning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Rhinovirus is the only option that is stable to alcohol and would survive the cleaning. Adenovirus, herpesvirus, and coronavirus are not stable to alcohol and would be killed during the clean-up.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Rhinovirus is the only option listed that is not enveloped, meaning it is more resistant to alcohol-based disinfectants. Adenovirus and herpesvirus are enveloped, but coronaviruses are also enveloped and would be more susceptible to the alcohol-based disinfectant. Therefore, option (B) Adenovirus and rhinovirus would be the most likely to still be alive after the cleaning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus and rhinovirus are both non-enveloped viruses, which means that they have a more robust protein coat that makes them more resistant to environmental stresses such as cleaning with alcohol. Enveloped viruses, like herpesvirus and coronavirus, have a lipid membrane that is more fragile and easily disrupted by alcohol, making them less likely to survive cleaning. Therefore, the most likely organisms to still be alive after cleaning with alcohol are adenovirus and rhinovirus (choice B).
